Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 IEEE International Symposium on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (IEEE DySPAN)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
IEEE International Symposium on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks, IEEE DySPAN 2019, will be held between November 11 and November 14, 2019, in Newark, NJ, USA. DySPAN is a unique symposium that gathers industry, academia and regulatory communities and facilities interactions between these communities on technical, business and policy aspects of spectrum. DySPAN 2019 offers not only technical paper presentations but also a wide range of other educational formats, including panels, tutorials, industry presentations, posters and keynote speeches by leaders from academia and industry. Spectrum engineering and policy are crucial for the continued advancement of future wireless networks that provide enormous societal benefits and DySPAN is well positioned to provide a venue for exchange of research ideas and training of the future workforce in this multi-disciplinary area.

The goal of this project is to support approximately 12 U.S.-based students with travel grants to attend DySPAN 2019. The students will have the opportunity to present their work or attend this symposium without accepted papers. Most students attending the symposium will be working on topics related to communications, spectrum, protocol and modeling. They may discover new directions for their research that can lead to new intellectual contributions. Announcement for the Student Travel Grant will be posted on the DySPAN 2019 website and the committee will conduct outreach (e.g. to N2Women and other minority groups) to attract potential attendees. The announcement specifically encourages the participation of women, undergraduates and beginning graduate students, and underrepresented minorities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty-one students including women and minority groups were awarded the travel grant for attending the 2019 IEEE International Symposium on Dynamic Spectrum Access Networks (DySPAN 2019) in Newark, NJ, U.S. The travel grant covered their partial expense of travel, lodging, and meals in Newark. The students engaged in a variety of conference activities including presenting their research results to their peers in the dynamic spectrum access network field, participating the student poster and demo sessions. In addition, all the students contribute to the conference as volunteers, which provide great opportunities for the students to be closely involved in interactions between researchers from all over the world. The participation of the rich program of the DySPAN 2019 and associated workshops exposed the students to new ideas and cutting-edge research in dynamic spectrum access network field.A total of 23 students from 14 universities applied for the travel grant. 21 students were selected based on the selection criteria described in the proposal. 6 out of 6 female applicants are selected to be awarded based on the selection criteria described in the proposal. Twenty students (i.e., 95.2%) awardees are junior Ph.D. students with one- or two-year experience. The participation of the graduate students has a great impact in shaping their careers, including identifying and/or sharpening their career goals during discussions with their peers, or discovering their role models among senior researchers that they will have met at the conference or increasing opportunities for their collaborations and their breadth of ideas and technical perspectives.
